history.content:
16A teaches you everything linear-algebraic from first principles.

Actually, you have seen some linear algebra in high school and junior high --- solving systems of linear equations. 

$$5x + 2y + 3z = 8$$

$$2x + 2y + 3z = 8$$

$$12x - 2y + z = 0$$

That sort of thing. 

If you're nervous, make sure you can do that. Review your high school geometry, trigonometry, and basic calculus. 

If you want to get ahead, and you're someone that really approaches the world rooted in physical intuition, maybe you could review your high school physics as it pertains to electromagnetism. The treatment in 16AB abstracts away most of the physics, but teaches circuit analysis more from a linear algebraic perspective that also engages with an intuition about how these quantities behave. 

16A has the same programming prereqs as 61A and also wants you to be at least taking 61A or DS8 in parallel. It doesn't really teach you Python programming, so if you want to review that, do so. 

But relax and be willing to work hard without distractions and an open curious mind. That's all that 16A really requires.

Personally, I went into EE16A with zero circuit experience and found the circuit portion of the class to be the most difficult. If you've taken Physics 7B, you might feel a bit more comfortable with circuits, but for me, building up intuition about circuits from scratch was fairly difficult. I might suggest looking at past 16A notes/ discussion worksheets, and following those up with MIT's OCW notes on circuits for examples that have a bit more explanation to help build a basis of knowledge about circuits.

children.subject:
Linear algebra intuition is super useful for EE16A. 

Check out the channel 3blue1brown on YouTube - there's a linear algebra series on there that my students from the last two semesters have found immensely useful for understanding intuitively what's going on. 

The videos are short and easy to watch!

history.content:
Hi folks,
What are some of the things that I need to self-study in order to get a leg up on EE16A next semester? (Side note: I haven't taken Math 54 yet, which means I have zero experience with linear algebra. Is it advisable to study Math 54 material first? If so, which areas of Math 54 should I focus on that are of significant use in EE16A?)
history.subject: Pre-EE16A course advice
